content: Heads up @T-compiler/meeting, because 11-26 is Thanksgiving in the US and many people will be out of office, we're moving next week's meeting to Wednesday, same time (2021-11-24T10:00:00-05:00). Meetings will resume on Thursdays the following week. Thanks!

Hey @T-compiler/meeting; the triage meeting will take place in about 2h
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

Scheduled checkins from:

  • WG-diagnostics by @Esteban Küber and @oli: anything to share?
  • WG-rustc-dev-guide by @Santiago Pastorino and @Yuki Okushi: anything to share?
Hi @T-compiler/meeting
Leave a :wave: above to show you’re present for this triage meeting (a day earlier than usual, to accommodate USA holiday tomorrow)

So let’s start off with five minutes for

Announcements
• :loudspeaker: next week December, 2nd, release of Rust stable 1.57

• Reminder: if you see a PR/issue that seems like there might be legal implications due to copywrite/IP/etc, please let the Core team know (or at least message pnkfelix or Wesley Wiser so we can pass it along).
Okay then, moving along
MCPs/FCPs

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • "Tier 3 target proposal: riscv64gc-linux-android (Android target for riscv64gc)" compiler-team#472

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "CI should exercise (subset of) tests under --stage 1" compiler-team#439 (last review activity: 3 months ago)
    • "Accept pc in place of unknown and unknown in place of pc for x86_64 and i?86 targets" compiler-team#441 (last review activity: 4 months ago)
    • "Make -Z binary-dep-depinfo the default behavior" compiler-team#464 (last review activity: about 54 days ago)
should there be some mechanism for marking MCPs as waiting-on-author?
(I am planning to follow-up on compiler-team#439 in some manner. To be honest I’m not sure why it wasn’t seconded, it sounded like there was positive responses)

Joshua Nelson said:

should there be some mechanism for marking MCPs as waiting-on-author?

waiting-on labels sound like a good idea
@pnkfelix recall that I asked you to say exactly which tests should run
happy to approve after that though!
yeah I guess that’s the main thing
okay. I’ll make a couple action items: one for that specific MCP, and one for labelling the MCP’s more generlly.

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • No pending FCP requests this time.

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "Unstable lints should be considered unknown" compiler-team#469
    • "Tracking Issue for cargo report future-incompat" rust#71249
    • "Tracking Issue for inline assembly (asm!)" rust#72016

• Accepted MCPs
    • No new accepted proposals this time.
  • Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • No new finished FCP (disposition merge) this time.
WG checkins
• @_WG-diagnostics_ by @Esteban Küber and @oli
(anything to report, @Esteban Küber or @oli ? I’m going to assume not unless one of you speaks up.)

• WG-rustc-dev-guide by @Santiago Pastorino and @Yuki Okushi (previous checkin):

    Most notable changes

    • Make subtree docs an overview and add link to clippy docs for details #1244
    • Describe drop elaboration #1240
    • Edit bootstrapping chapter #1239
    • Add documentation for LLVM CFI support #1234

    Most notable WIPs

    • Document more compiletest headers. #1249
    • Added detail to codegen section #1216
    • Document inert vs active attributes #1110
    • Explain the new valtree system for type level constants. #1097
Backport nominations
T-compiler stable / T-compiler beta

pnkfelix said:

(anything to report, Esteban Küber or oli ? I’m going to assume not unless one of you speaks up.)

nope, just small things, nothing major happening

• "relate lifetime in TypeOutlives bounds on drop impls" rust#90840
    • fixes p-critical unsoundness rust#90838
    • @pnkfelix has also produced a scope-limited backport in rust#91136
    • @Jack Huey comments on rust#91136 on which of the two is better suited for a backport
what does :taxi: mean here :laughing:
oops
its self-explanatory. :taxi: is :taxi:
I don't see a strong reason to prefer #91136 over #90840 but I think we should backport one of them.
Yes we should backport one of them
and I admit, even while I was constructing #91136, I was wondering if it was worth the effort of teasing it out
#90840 looks small enough
is it risky?
but I also still worry that #90840 is enabling a code path that clearly isn’t tested enough
or rather, not #90840 iself
#87770 is what enabled the code path that was not tested enough
if your PR is backported we just end up with my fix on stable in a month or so right?
and #91136 restricts it more strictly than #90840 did
if my PR is backported to beta, then my PR ends up in stable in week
and your fix ends up in the next release, six weeks after that
..bit more than a month right
yep
I clearly am worried about risk here.
@pnkfelix is the test coverage better for you version?
you mean, because I added a new test?
but wait, I think I didn’t… let me double check
Well, I'm mostly trying to find out how to decide which version is preferable for backporting :)
the test I added was in #90840 too
(I had constructed a fresh test from the original bug, and then discovered that #90840 had it too.)
I’m okay with backporting PR #90840
and I think the team is overall in favor of it too
So lets just do that and move along
I’ll close PR #91136

• "relate lifetime in TypeOutlives bounds on drop impls" rust#90840
    • see beta nomination
At this point I think we’re so close to the release that we just do the beta backport now, and let that roll into next week’s release
right ?
@simulacrum that works out for overall timing, right? Assuming #90840 is backported soon?
I’ll assume yes.

T-rustdoc stable / T-rustdoc beta

  • No beta nominations for T-rustdoc this time.
  • No stable nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

  • No PRs waiting for T-compiler
the beta branch is friday, so I think that should work
okay

Oldest PRs waiting for review

T-compiler
• "Add long explanation for E0726" rust#87655 (last review activity: 3 months ago)
@GuillaumeGomez does this need another round of review from you?
Or should we reassign?
There’s a general tracking issue for these things on #61137
Just a thought, but we haven't gotten through the Nominated issues in several weeks. I would suggest we delay the Oldest PRs section until the end of the meeting.
@Wesley Wiser okay
I’m good with that
lets skip delay remaining Oldest PRs

pnkfelix said:

  • "Add long explanation for E0726" rust#87655 (last review activity: 3 months ago)

(this should be waiting-on-author I think, ci is failing)
hn,, it only because unmergable recently
but yeah
okay
and oh the CI failures are long standing
so yeah, you are right
lets fix that labelling then

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 4 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 2 of those are unassigned
  • 79 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 55 of those are unassigned
  • 2 P-critical, 4 P-high, 2 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 0 P-critical, 2 P-high, 2 P-medium, 1 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 4 P-critical, 46 P-high, 84 P-medium, 12 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

• "Miscompilation where binding only some fields leaks the others" rust#90752
    • See nominations
(… hmm… forward referencing in agenda here is weird…)

• "Miscompilation where binding only some fields leaks the others" rust#90752
    • @tmandry nominated
    • great writeup from @Dylan MacKenzie (ecstatic-morse), suggests a quick fix
    • Opened PR rust#90788 that implements the quick fix suggested. PR is beiung reviewed.
    • wg-prio assigned P-critical, but being a regression from stable probably not a release blocker?

pnkfelix said:

  • "Miscompilation where binding only some fields leaks the others" rust#90752
    • See nominations

^ this is the issue for the backported PR
err uh
never mind, sorry
Yeah I also inferred it was talking about a backport nomination but it's not.
this is not a release blocker, right?
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/90788 has already been merged
but not nominated for backport
(which it probably should have been)

pnkfelix said:

this is not a release blocker, right?

not sure what you mean? it's p-critical
okay
lets beta nominate PR #90788 now
The issue was injected in Feb 2020.
Given the PR has only landed in nightly within the last 24 hours, I'm hesitant to release it to stable next week.
Yeah, the timing is unfortunate
but I’m with wesley there
lets not try to get this into the 1.57.0 release
I'm fairly confident the fix is correct but we also lack experienced reviewers in this area which is also contributing to my hesitancy.
what we might consider is nominating it for a stable-backport in. 1.57.x for x > 0 release?
that makes sense to me
Yeah, arguablty I should have looked at to since I do know that dataflow code
but its too late now
Well, if you have a chance, please do!
It's always possible you could catch an issue before it makes it to stable.
right ,. i meant “too late” in terms of “getting it in a week ago” :)
so okay, decling to beta backport, but leaving open option of a stable nomination in the future.
but … I think we will not stable nominate yet … ?
(and instead, just make sure that stable-to-stable regression ticket stays open, right?)
next
if we stable-nominate now it would for 1.56.x (me thinks?), so better after 1.57 is out, right?
Perhaps we need to talk with T-infra and see if they will consider giving us a heads up before point releases in case there are additional fixes we think should go out?
right. do not stable nomninate now

Wesley Wiser said:

Perhaps we need to talk with T-infra and see if they will consider giving us a heads up before point releases in case there are additional fixes we think should go out?

historically I think we’ve tried to just make the decisions up front, indepednent of whatever T-infra is deciding
and while I would opt to continue striving for that model
I also agree that it would make sense to be aware of planned point releases
since that might heighten interest in trying to get some stable nominations done

• "Unsound drop due to imperfect lifetime checks" rust#90838
    • Has two PR fixing this: rust#90840 and rust#91136 from @pnkfelix (see backports)
(alkready discssued)

• "Implied bounds by associated types as function parameters are inconsistent in an unsound way." rust#91068
    • opened by @Frank Steffahn, also bisected to PR rust#88312
    • discussion about reverting rust#88312

I'd like to mention that #91068 is a new regression on 1.56, a soundness issue that you can run into in realistic code, at least in the sense that the fix for the issue can break code (code that is missing certain lifetime bounds that used to be required and are supposed to be required) – after all, I found the bug from code on the users forum which would be affected by a fix – and a revert of #88312 seems like a way to quickly fix the issue in 1.57 already. (So compared to a 1.58-only fix, this would mean significantly less time for people to write code that will be broken by the bugfix.)

Also note that the bug that #88312 fixed was a requires-nightly bug (involving GATs), so there should be no downside to reverting #88312. There doesn't exist any PR for doing the revert yet, and I haven't tested if reverting is straightforward.

pnkfelix said:

Wesley Wiser said:

Perhaps we need to talk with T-infra and see if they will consider giving us a heads up before point releases in case there are additional fixes we think should go out?

historically I think we’ve tried to just make the decisions up front, indepednent of whatever T-infra is deciding

FWIW this is why I think it's especially important to stable nominate even if we don't think it needs a point release on its own. That way the release team doesn't have to deal with NDAs if there's a point release going out for a security issue.
It certainly sounds like we shoudl revert PR #88312
I was going to talk about that with Niko today, but we didn't meet
I'm going to open a revert PR

Joshua Nelson said:

FWIW this is why I think it's especially important to stable nominate even if we don't think it needs a point release on its own. That way the release team doesn't have to deal with NDAs if there's a point release going out for a security issue.

yes, yes, I jkust meant I didn’t want to stable-nominate today
Well, effective revert
because I didn’t want it to be interpreted as meaning that we were targetting the 1.57 release. Arguably taht could be made clear in a comment.
(see long-standing issue that our backport nomination labelling system really breaks down around release time…)
okay. Rvert planned. Great.
@Jack Huey so the revert should hapepn And be beta-backported … by friday …?
is that too aggressive?
Yes. I dont think it's too aggressive
I think this is pretty safe.

Joshua Nelson said:

pnkfelix said:

Wesley Wiser said:

Perhaps we need to talk with T-infra and see if they will consider giving us a heads up before point releases in case there are additional fixes we think should go out?

historically I think we’ve tried to just make the decisions up front, indepednent of whatever T-infra is deciding

FWIW this is why I think it's especially important to stable nominate even if we don't think it needs a point release on its own. That way the release team doesn't have to deal with NDAs if there's a point release going out for a security issue.

I think we need a way to distinguish between "stable-backport-approved please cut a release for this" and "stable-backport-approved only include this if we're making a release anyway".

My understanding is that (in the wider OSS community) users know there is going to be an important security update released on x day, they just don't know what's in it. NDAs shouldn't affect the infra team letting us know a point release is going to be made soon. :smile:
it sounds aggressive. @Jack Huey see what you come up with for the revert. If you can cleanly apply a revert against beta, then great.
Will do
@Jack Huey if there’s doubts about the cleanliness of a revert on beta, do let @pnkfelix and @Wesley Wiser know.
great thanks!

• "Huge compile-time regression in beta/nightly" rust#91128
    • we have a reproducible example
    • seems correlated to the new LLVM pass-manager (disabling it solves the issue)
    • (the new LLVM pass-manager will enter in stable and is enabled by default)
Or if you feel you need to hand off the work, please also let us know.
It's pretty simple. Just removing like 4 lines
Already basically have it, just need to test
Could even do that on 1.56.x and pretend the regression never happened?

pnkfelix said:

  • "Huge compile-time regression in beta/nightly" rust#91128
    • we have a reproducible example
    • seems correlated to the new LLVM pass-manager (disabling it solves the issue)
    • (the new LLVM pass-manager will enter in stable and is enabled by default)

hmm. The new pass managers sped up compiles for a lot of people, right?
yes
Okay
but not sure if it sped them up exponentially
so we have to decide whether to disable the new pass manager in 1.57
(i.e. in beta before friday)
it sounds like we should consider it
Does anyone in wg-llvm have thoughts? cc @nagisa @Nikita Popov
it also sounds like we should consider exposing a -C flag here?
Did we llvm upgrade in 1.57 or just enable the new pass manager?

pnkfelix said:

it also sounds like we should consider exposing a -C flag here?

there's already -C llvm-args, right? does that allow controlling the pass manager?
If we both upgraded llvm and enabled NewPM, I'm slightly concerned we haven't done testing with the old PM.

Joshua Nelson said:

pnkfelix said:

it also sounds like we should consider exposing a -C flag here?

there's already -C llvm-args, right? does that allow controlling the pass manager?

I think its non trivial to get the list of passes appropriate arguments to feed in? But maybe I’m wrong.
There alreaady is RUSTFLAGS="-Z new-llvm-pass-manager=no"
@Hans Kratz right, my point is that isn’t available on non-nightly.
You can't shouldn't use that on stable though
Lets put it this way
my gut tells me “disable new pass manager now, on nightly and beta"
To the best of my knowledge there's some contention about addressing the underlying problems upstream.
does someone want to objedct?
newPM being entirely disabled is also not a great option though, given that next release cycle oldPM is being removed entirely IIRC.
I take it a crater run didn't uncover any similar regressions in the ecosystem? Since this report comes from a closed source crate.
Do crater runs report compile-time regressions?
I would think it would time out right?
The reported issue is exponential.
hmm
disabling on beta and nightly buys us time
Before, compiling the crate would take around 1 minute 30 seconds in automation. Now if I'm using the nightly channel, it seems to take around an hour or so.
during which we can try to work witrh LLVM upstream
and figure out either the right fix, or argue that its too soon to remove oldPM ?

nagisa said:

To the best of my knowledge there's some contention about addressing the underlying problems upstream.

why is this contentious?
(we had hoped to get around to the nominated issues but I’m thinking that is unlikely to happen…)
(it seems pretty aggressive to both remove the old version and not fix the regressions in the new version)
https://reviews.llvm.org/D98481 see this diff for discussion on a fix for one of these issues.
In summary, there are some people advocating for simple size limits rathar than a more proper solution (not inlining self-recursive stuff)
so far the main objection I’ve heard to disabling NewPM is that gives us less time to test NewPM before it goes away on the LLVM side
but that “just" means that LLVM upgrades will be delayed until this is resolved (and we get subsequent time to test NewPM again)
I think it may be reasonable to disable on beta and backport the fix to nightly perhaps.
well, what I’m suggesting is: disable on beta and nightly, then reenable on ngihtly once we have a fix as well
does that sound okay to you, @nagisa ?
My concern with disabling on nightly is that we might simply never reenable it, but I guess it does make sense to me if we don't have any other options.
i think we will reenable it. It sounds like we are going to be forced to do so. :)
would "disable on beta" mean that 1.57 would have it disabled already?
@mw right, I’m trying to say: Disable for 1.57-stable, and for 1.58-beta
maybe we backport a reenable to 1.58-beta
okay?
Who can own doing this. @nagisa do you have time?
disabling for 1.57/58 seems reasonable. I can make a PR for this tonight, sure.
awesome, thank you so much

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

• "Compilation appears to loop indefinitely " rust#89195
    • discussed last week
      • @pnkfelix self assigned as reminder to reach out to Kyle Huey and schedule chat with @Aaron Hill
(I failed to follwo through here. its been … a hard week…)

• "regression: rustc suggests .as_ref() at incorrect location and other spans have regressed" rust#90286
    • @Esteban Küber comments wrt to a revert that it would cause another bug to resurface, would try to prepare a fix before the next release

• "DWARF info for static vars in lib crates has stopped being produced reliably in LTO builds" rust#90357
    • bisection seems to point to rust#89041 but cuviper suggests could be a dupe of rust#90301 and #89041 possibly just exacerbated the LLVM issue
    • also reproduces on nightly
(I’ve spent some time looking into #90357. It certainly isnt’ going to block the 1.57 release. We’ll live with the less-high quality debuginfo for now.)
Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

• "Undefined reference to getauxval in function init_have_lse_atomics when compiling to nightly aarch64-unknown-linux-musl" rust#89626
    • Seems that it now happens also on beta, which will become stable in a week
    • @Hans Kratz suggest as a workaround
    • discussed previously
    • as a workaround -Clinker=rust-lld works
    • Issue should be fixed by rust#90527 + libc#2272 as soon as the fixed libc 0.2.107 is merged, see rust#90681
wow that’s a lot of context to load

Issue should be fixed by rust#90527 + libc#2272 as soon as the fixed libc 0.2.107 is merged, see rust#90681

this is the important summary
Okay, and #90681 was blokced by a libc release, but now that has happened
released but not yet ported by T-libs, afaics
does PR #90527 need to be backported by Friday?
#90681 is waiting on them
or is the workaround good enough that we should not try to backport PR #90527 ?
I’m pretty uncomfortable with teh number of other backports we’re doing
so I’d prefer to just let this bug persist into 1.57
can someone convince me I’m wrong?
seems reasonable
its very confusing because the labels implied this was only a stable-to-nightly provlem
I guess we just failed to update the labels… :(
The alternative would be to just disable inline-atomics on aarch64-unknown-linux-musl for the beta. That would be a minimal change: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/90044/files
@simulacrum is this a place where we could/should have used Milestone to track impact?

Hans Kratz said:

The alternative would be to just disable inline-atomics on aarch64-unknown-linux-musl for the beta. That would be a minimal change: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/90044/files

Is there a downside to that? Runtime performance?
Yes, on modern CPUs. But at least it would compile.
So @Hans Kratz is suggesting a beta-backport of PR #90044, but taht hasn’t landed in nightly either
sorry, I don’t think I can get on board for that...
i can see that this is frustrating, since that PR was open back at the beginning of October
Yes, I'd also prefer not to rush anything here

(Also, independent from all this, @Josh Triplett did a good job of convincing me that we should be investing in some form of linker group support. Not necessarily PR #85805, but some kind of support.)
okay we are way way way over time
I want to thank you all for attending this non-standard meeting time

The workaround is pretty easy to Google and aarch64-unknown-linux-musl is not that common so it might no be that bad. But just making sure that it is clear: it affects any code compiled for this platform, even helloworld.
ugh. And the scope of the impact of PR #90044 is itself obvuously limited to just aarch64-unknown-linux-musl...
Um
Okay.
Okay, lets beta-nominate it as well, I guess
beta backport for 1.57: " Restrict aarch64 outline atomics to glibc for now." #90044
(don’t understand why I keep hitting :taxi: . Iguess I just want to driveaway from here)
I'm for backporting if we can be reasonably sure that there's no soundness risks here
it looks straightforward enough
lets plan to backport, aasusming it lands on nightly very soon
like, today.
@Jubilee should that review be assigned to someone else, or do you think you’ll have time for it today?
I’ll post a comment on the PR
Heyhey.
didn't see it got an update, will review.
Hey, hi. It sounds like PR #90044 might be a priority to get into 1.57
(for which beta backports are due this friday)

Jubilee said:

didn't see it got an update, will review.

great thanks awesome
Okay, and with that, 18 minutes over the meeting time, lets call it quits for this meeting.
I do recommend people go check out the agenda for the other stuff
Perforance triage was especially interesting this week. more than 2x improvement on diesel compilation time!!!
with that, bye to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting; thanks for attending!!!

pnkfelix said:

Perforance triage was especially interesting this week. more than 2x improvement on diesel compilation time!!!

(diesel-doc, not diesel-opt)
oh, heh, I misinterpretd that
yeah there's an open issue on the perf repo to make it more clear
-0.83% on diesel opt. Not quite so impressive. :)
https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-perf/issues/1048
I even looked at that compare page several times and repeatedly overlooked the “doc” part of “diesel doc"
probably because my eyes kept staring at the -58.14%
human error, my very personal nemesis

pnkfelix said:

GuillaumeGomez does this need another round of review from you?

I'm waiting for the contributor to fix the CI failure first

Draft for next week's agenda available at:
https://hackmd.io/R_-u5cmyQtmcPSL8sNtbuw

Scheduled checkins from:

  • @_wg-incr-comp_ by @pnkfelix and @Wesley Wiser
  • @_WG-llvm_ by @nagisa
